p: Hepatitis E virus is the main cause of acute hepatitis worldwide, causing more than 20 million infections and more than 60,000 deaths per year [ 1]. HEV was first characterized in 1955 from an outbreak in New Delhi, India, when it was initially named non-A/non-B hepatitis. In 1983, the virus was named HEV to reflect its tendency to cause epidemics of enteric infections [ 2]. Hepatitis E infections in Europe have historically been caused by travelers returning from endemic countries, but in the last decade, autochthonous cases have greatly increased and have been associated with zoonotic transmission, mainly through the consumption of poorly cooked pork meat or liver-derived meat products [ 3, 4, 5].
